nodes.bodyText: Can we remove these CARBON-371 comments?
Remove the comment.

If bypassCache is null, shouldn't this be "false" instead of "true"?  Also, rather than parse the boolean, I would look for "true" and set it or otherwise it should always just be false (regardless of the value).

I'm not sure we want this particular Map class (which is a JAX-RS dependency) to be required outside elide-core.   We may want RequestScope to keep the headers private and instead have a public method to ask for a particular header.
Rather than redefine these methods twice, let's put them in a common class (HeaderUtils) or something like that.
remove.
Remove
We don't want to duplicate all of this logic.

nodes.bodyText: We don't want to duplicate all of this logic.
bypassCache instead of bypassingCache
It doesn't look like we remove auth headers here.
We should make a copy of the requestHeaders map (and return it) rather than modify the input map.
This test is the same as the prior.  Maybe we should look at the cache metrics for something different between the tests?

     })
-    public void jsonApiGetTest(@Autowired MeterRegistry metrics) {
-        when()
-                .get("/json/stats?fields[stats]=measure")
-                .then()
-                .body(equalTo(
-                        data(
-                                resource(
-                                        type("stats"),
-                                        id("0"),
-                                        attributes(
-                                                attr("measure", 250)
-                                        )
+    public void jsonApiGetTestNoCache(@Autowired MeterRegistry metrics) {
+
+        Map<String, String> requestHeaders = new HashMap<>();
+        requestHeaders.put("bypassCache", "true");
+
+        given().headers(requestHeaders)
+        .get("/json/stats?fields[stats]=measure")
+        .then()
+        .body(equalTo(
+                data(
+                        resource(
+                                type("stats"),
+                                id("0"),
+                                attributes(
+                                        attr("measure", 250)
                                 )
-                        ).toJSON())
-                )
-                .statusCode(HttpStatus.SC_OK);
+                        )
+                ).toJSON())
+        )
+        .statusCode(HttpStatus.SC_OK);
+        assertFalse(metrics
+                .get("cache.gets")
+                .tags("cache", "elideQueryCache", "result", "miss")
+                .functionCounter().count() > 0);
+    }
+
+    @Test
+    @Sql(statements = {
+            "DROP TABLE Stats IF EXISTS;",
+            "CREATE TABLE Stats(id int, measure int, dimension VARCHAR(255));",
+            "INSERT INTO Stats (id, measure, dimension) VALUES\n"
+                    + "\t\t(1,100,'Foo'),"
+                    + "\t\t(2,150,'Bar');"
+    })
+    public void jsonApiGetTestWithCache(@Autowired MeterRegistry metrics) {
 
-        // query cache was active and publishing metrics
+        Map<String, String> requestHeaders = new HashMap<>();
+        requestHeaders.put("bypassCache", "false");
+
+        given().headers(requestHeaders)
+        .get("/json/stats?fields[stats]=measure")
+        .then()
+        .body(equalTo(
+                data(
+                        resource(
+                                type("stats"),
+                                id("0"),
+                                attributes(
+                                        attr("measure", 250)
+                                )
+                        )
+                ).toJSON())
+        )
+        .statusCode(HttpStatus.SC_OK);

nodes.bodyText: Add @Override
It looks like spacing of these comments is all messed up.
I think something is off in your environment?
I think when I was resolving conflicts I used the eclipse compare with older version and pulled changes. That might have messed up the formatting

We can commonize this logic with HeaderUtils.
Spring has a class called HttpHeaders and JaXRS has a class called MultivalueMap.  Both extends Map<String, List<String>> .
We can commonize removing auth headers and the like by using the Java standard.
This means requestScope should probably have a Map<String, List> instead of a Multivalued map.
We shouldn't catch a NPE.  We should prevent it from happening.  What is resulting in an NPE?
If this is what is causing the NPE, instead of passing null, we can create an empty HashMap here.
Same comment.
Same comment.
Same comment.
empty hashmap.
empty hashmap.
empty hashmap.
empty hashmap.
I don't see the Override annotation.
empty hashmap.

nodes.bodyText: Let's make this a boolean argument.
This should move into the calling code.  It is a strange contract to accept a string header here.
This is resolved now in elide-5.x.  You can just rebase your PR to pick up the fix.
